item.title: Labor doubts Lib MP Crewther's eligibility - Daily Telegraph
item.description:
Labor doubts Lib MP Crewther's eligibility  Daily Telegraph

Another Liberal MP could be ineligible to sit in federal parliament, with Labor releasing legal advice showing his financial interests could be a problem.

item.title: Legal advice on Liberal MP’s business interest raising doubts on his future - The Mercury
item.description:
Legal advice on Liberal MP’s business interest raising doubts on his future  The Mercury

A leading Melbourne barrister has said he believes a Victorian Liberal MP is ineligible to sit in parliament because he has an indirect pecuniary interest in a ...

A leading Melbourne barrister has said he believes a Victorian Liberal MP is ineligible to sit in parliament because he has an indirect pecuniary interest in a ...

item.title: Labor to target Peter Dutton, Chris Crewther over Section 44 - The Australian
item.description:
Labor to target Peter Dutton, Chris Crewther over Section 44  The Australian

Bill Shorten will target Liberal MPs Peter Dutton and Chris Crewther over their eligibility to sit in parliament in the years last sitting fortnight.

item.title: Labor pushes for Liberal MP Chris Crewther to be referred to High Court - The Australian
item.description:
Labor pushes for Liberal MP Chris Crewther to be referred to High Court  The Australian

Labor has called for Victorian Liberal MP Chris Crewther to be referred to the High Court as soon as parliament returns after he armed himself with legal advice ...

item.title: Eligibility focus now on Crewther - The Australian
item.description:
Eligibility focus now on Crewther  The Australian

Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutto­n appears set to survive the year without being referred to the High Court, as Labor tries to raise fresh doubt over the eligibility of Liberal MP Chris Crewther. Bill Shorten’s office has released legal advice from Matthew Collins QC, who specialises in media and commercial law, ­stating that Mr Crewther is incapabl­e of sitting in the House of Representatives under section 44 of the Constitution because of an investment his family super fund has in ­Gretals Australia. The Australian understands there are no “imminent moves” to try to refer him or Mr Dutto...

item.title: Legal advice crucial on eligibility - The Australian
item.description:
Legal advice crucial on eligibility  The Australian

Independent MP Rebekha Sharkie wants a stronger threshold to determine which MPs go to the High Court under section 44 of the Constitution, as key crossbenchers and the government consider a mass referral that includes Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton. The Centre Alliance MP said the Solicitor-General Stephen Donaghue QC could provide advice on members under an eligibility cloud. If the government or Labor attempted to refer a parliamentarian who according to Dr Donaghue’s advice still had questions to answer, they should be referred. “My position is that Peter Dutton has questions to ans...

item.title: Federal politicians sift through the entrails of Victorian Labor's thumping win - ABC News
item.description:
Federal politicians sift through the entrails of Victorian Labor's thumping win  ABC News

By political editor Andrew Probyn and political reporter Matthew Doran The 'Dan-slide' in Victoria offers grim tidings for the federal Coalition and succour for Bill Shorten's Opposition. For the Liberals it once again confirms the dangerous transactional costs of the August coup when Malcolm Turnbull was ousted. If replicated at the next federal election, it would see Labor pick up seats that have long been blue, including those held by members who plotted against Mr Turnbull in favour of Peter Dutton. Among the electorates now being discussed as potential losses for the Liberals are Deaki...

item.title: Liberal crisis talks trigger deep divisions in Canberra - The Advertiser
item.description:
Liberal crisis talks trigger deep divisions in Canberra  The Advertiser

The almost 90-minute “robust” meeting between Victorian federal MPs, in the company of Prime Minister Scott Morrison, came amid warnings of an electorate wipe out based on the Andrews Government’s massive victory at the weekend. Ms O’Dwyer launched a fierce criticism of the party’s officials and laid the blame on “ideological” warriors who had recruited members from conservative religious groups in an attempt to hijack the party’s positions on social issues. JAMES CAMPBELL: LIBERAL MARRIAGE OVER, WHAT HAPPENS NEXT? LIBERAL HEAVYWEIGHTS TURN ON KROGER VICTORIAN STATE ELECTION: HOW EACH UNDEC...

item.title: Kroger war risk for PM - The Australian
item.description:
Kroger war risk for PM  The Australian

In what is becoming an increasingly hostile battle, a number of cabinet ministers and frontbench MPs have publicly backed Mr Kroger in an attempt to stare down colleagues supportive of Mr Reith challenging for the presidency. While Mr Turnbull is refusing to intervene, senior party sources claim his authority is at risk of being undermined with the perception that he is aligned with those behind the push against Mr Kroger as part of a campaign to seize back control of the party. Health Minister Greg Hunt and Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg have urged the membership to stick with Mr Kroger, ...

item.title: $500m to pay for promises - The Australian
item.description:
$500m to pay for promises  The Australian

The targeted spending includes health and education projects for some of the nation’s most marginal electorates, as well as cash promised for entire states to fund “jobs and growth” pledges during the campaign. But it also includes $250m for projects in Townsville that failed to prevent the key seat of Herbert swinging to Labor, while another $72.5m promised for Tasmania was not enough to save the Coalition’s three lower house seats in that state. The Australian’s analysis of the Coalition election platform shows the money promised for key seats will add about $540.2m in spending in the bud...

item.title: Adventures of a bit player - The Australian
item.description:
Adventures of a bit player  The Australian

A “hush hush’’ meeting with Calabrian businessmen and the state’s next premier at a lobster restaurant. A promise to tip a “swag of money’’ into the party’s barren coffers before the next election. Bottles of Grange. Men with bottle. And at the centre of it, a semi-retired party volunteer whose last paid gig was working casual shifts in the Frankston office of Chris Crewther, a newbie federal MP. Macmillan is variously described as a Walter Mitty character, a bit of a duffer and just plain odd. He is not malicious and no one questions his loyalty to the party. But he is known as having a bi...

item.title: Liberal politician Stuart Robert spent more than any other MP on personalised stationery - ABC News
item.description:
Liberal politician Stuart Robert spent more than any other MP on personalised stationery  ABC News

Liberal politician Stuart Robert spent almost $17,000 of taxpayers' money on "personalised letterhead stationery" during the final weeks of the financial year, more than five times the typical spend for an MP. Key points: - MPs spent $15 million on printing and communications in the first half of 2018 - More than $20,000 was spent on books, much of it in June, and another $793,000 on flags - One senator spent more than $20,000 on web services Expense records show the Member for Fadden bought 210,000 items on June 12 — 10 weeks before he was named Assistant Treasurer. His $16,880 bill was mo...
